question: I think we can begin... First parole request Carter "Doc" McCoy... is legal counsel present?

Carter McCoy, one to five years sentence for armed robbery, first offense in the State of Texas, wanted by the State of Ohio for assault with a deadly weapon and armed robbery... That is correct. Very well. Mr. McCoy has served four years of his sentence. Prison record satisfactory. Applied for parole on September 5th of this year... Remarks? Notice is taken. The Board met in closed chambers last week... have you reached a decision regarding Mr. McCoy's request for parole?
answer: His face is taut. lowers his eyes, then looks up at his lawyer. The lawyer avoids Doc's glance., he shuffles the papers in front of him, begins stuffing them into his briefcase.

question: Class - regular?
Jesus. Carol Ainsley?
The Doctor took out McGovern for her.
answer: She only rides winning - Class easy class.

question: How are you, Mrs. McCoy?
answer: Ready to talk about my husband, Mr. Beynon.

question: So the good Doctor comes up again. Please sit down.
answer: He's asked me to come and see you.

question: Why? Can I help?
Hello, Doc.
You okay?
answer: I'm a lot better off than I was an hour ago.

question: You want to drive?
answer: My license expired, let's get out of here.

question: Sure... I'm sorry I was late... I got my hair done... the girl was slow.
Feel good?
Where do you want to go?
answer: I want to take a walk. It doesn't look like that.

question: What do you mean? You've never been there.
answer: I've been there every day for the last four years. What's Beynon got set up?

question: Small town, small bank, big money.
I've been doing my homework.
Better than old times.
answer: I hope so. I am not looking forward to another stretch.

question: I made a mistake. I'll never make another one.
answer: Where did you get them developed?

question: Assumed name... Houston.
Half a million.
answer: That Beynon's got a long arm.

question: What do you want for dinner?
How does it taste?
answer: Just the way I remembered. You been okay?

question: Pretty good... Made a quick trip to Oregon, saw my brother and the kids. Figured it would be my last chance, unless they wanted to travel.
Fatter... some things never change.
Nothing's been boring since you found me.
No. It's been a long time.
After four years and now the question comes up.
answer: Couldn't handle it then. Now I can.

question: I'm still here, Doc.
answer: Oh Christ... I guess I'm kind of...

question: It's all right.
We've got time. We've got a lot of time. I can help you.
Sure.
Listen, I'm just as nervous as you are.
Really. Let me make you feel good, Doctor. How was it?
I was going to fix you breakfast.
I bought you a lot of new things.
answer: Yeah, well, I think I'll stick with what I've got.

question: Suit yourself.
$250,000 right off the top.
You got the parole, didn't you?
answer: Thanks again. I 'm glad you waited.

question: I couldn't have... much longer.
But I got you out. Didn't I, Doc. I did it. I got you out.

I laugh when I feel happy. Sometimes just thinking of you made me laugh. I had a lot of that. And other times that wasn't enough. I had a lot of that too. I know you find it hard to believe, I'm happy just loving you.
But sometimes I cried a lot too.
Want to cry now?
You gotta be kidding.
answer: Not at all, just a pleasant way to have lunch. Glad to see you in civilian clothes.

question: All it takes is a long arm.
answer: Hard to judge how these things happen. The Parole Board almost never reverses their decisions.

question: I guess it was because I was a model prisoner.
answer: This is the only time you and I meet in public. Any business with me, handle it with him... You're back with your own people now. Got you some professionals.

question: I get my own help.
answer: You run the job, but I run the show. You got two weeks to set it up.

question: What about them?
answer: They're mine. The one with the moustache is my brother. They stay out of it. We stay clean. Rudy Butler, Frank Jackson...

question: I heard about you. You work with Miller.
answer: You're out of touch. Cops blew him up.

question: Where?
You were with him?
What about you?
I'd like an application for a checking account.
answer: Could I get change for this fifty please? ... Bank President, three tellers and one guard...

question: Usually on the right side as you go in.
answer: Nail him first, be careful he doesn't panic and want to shoot somebody. Local police have one car, a rover, shouldn't be in the vicinity at the time we hit unless it's answering an emergency call... if the cop car shows up remember it doesn't have any automatic weapons. Only a shotgun braced on the dashboard. Get into a tight spot, you'll be out of range at forty yards. Then they're down to their side guns.

question: For exits off Main Street.
answer: Should be light traffic that time of day... the Bank Guard carries a .38. These will stop an M.2 at fifty yards. Just in case someone gets a shot off.

question: Should be light traffic that time of day... the Bank Guard carries a .38. These will stop an M.2 at fifty yards. Just in case someone gets a shot off.
answer: I worked ten years without one, I don't need one now.

question: Suit yourself.
Two.
Chambers - Reilly. Time lock opens 20 minutes before they start doing business...
One-inch stuff on a three-number combination.
I 'm handling the fine stuff. You're back up all the way...
I'll hang on to these. We don't need them till we get to Gollies. Okay. Any questions?
answer: Aren't we going a little hard?

question: What do you have in mind?
answer: It's just a walk-in bank. You don't have to be Dillinger for this one.

question: Dillinger got killed. Tell Beynon I want no mistakes.
Beynon has to be alone at the drop ... one car at the ranch and that's it. I won't have the money... she won't know where it is until I'm sure it's clear.
Make sure everybody does.
My mind's not on guessing games.
If it's funny I'm going to laugh.
answer: I feel like the night before the first day of school.

question: That bad? You promised not to laugh.
answer: It will be such a relief not to have to think about it any more.

question: Waiting's hard. You never learn how.
answer: You know I've actually gotten tired waiting sometimes... worn out waiting.

question: At least you were outside.
answer: It doesn!t make much difference where you are, if you're waiting, Doc.

question: Bullshit.
I know you do. But it is different. It's different. We'll be all right tomorrow.
answer: We are always going to be all right tomorrow. I'd like to be all right a few todays.

question: We're going to have a lot of those, We're just going to get the money and then go all the way.
Two feet forward... Okay.
Just pick it up.
Where's Jackson?
answer: He didn't make it, Doc... you didn't either.

question: How did you know? What about the bank?
answer: Jackson panicked and nailed the guard.

question: Oh, Christ.
answer: We got between four and five.

question: Doc...
answer: I see it... They're looking for three men... remember? What's the problem?

question: They checked in.
answer: Call the ranch, tell Beynotr we'll leave his cut here --

question: Why?
So what. I've got to give him his money. That was our end of the deal.
answer: He might be ready to chop us up.

question: Do it my way. Tell me about Beynon's ranch.
answer: I've never "been there... When we met it was in his office. Do you trust him?

question: I just figure the percentages. He wouldn't try a cross until he's got the money.
answer: Let's send his cut back -- Just keep going.

question: If we make a mistake., he'll burn us. You make a deal, you're always better keeping your end up.
answer: I don't want to go there.

question: Do it my way. You can wait here... I'll wrap it up fast.
Beynon.
Three... Rudy got ambitious.
That's right.
What about her? Let's c ut up the money, I want to get North.
answer: Your wife told me no one would be killed.

question: You hired Jackson and Rudy., not me.
answer: They may nail me into this now, McCoy.

question: That's your problem.
answer: You know, you and I may be two of a kind.

question: No way. I always do my own work.
answer: Here. I understand the way you feel. As a matter of fact, you and I might share a great many feelings...

question: I'm in a hurry.
answer: You still don't get the picture do you? I've always heard what a smart ass operator you are.

question: No applause!
answer: Let's examine the situation. One, an extremely attractive woman. Then, there's the woman's husband, a skillful bank robber serving a long sentence in prison. Three, a man with political influence, a man who can easily get a parole for a convict... why should he? A simple reason, McCoy. The obvious reason. To rob a bank.

question: I knew that life didn't add up to the obvious when I was 8.
answer: What do you add up to here?

question: One. The radio's rappin' about $750^000. We only got a half a million.
answer: A little more was taken out before. My brother's a director of that Bank, Mr. McCoy... I had a few pressing debts.

question: So we did that crackerbox... to cover for you.
answer: The obvious. But we are both not interested in that right now.

question: No. My old lady must have made a lot of promises.
answer: Close... but it takes a hell of a lot more than promises to pull the kind of strings I pulled.

question: I bet.
answer: You wouldn't have come here when you were eight3 Mr. McCoy. Don't think too badly of her... After all, you were in jail a long time and she is a healthy young woman.

question: Get it over with... Stupid. Why didn't you tell me?
answer: There wasn't any way to explain it.

question: Yeah.
When I got out, why didn't you tell me where it was?
answer: What the hell do you want? Mary Tyler Moore?

question: Who's she?
If you don't start telling the truth...
What's the damage?
answer: Collar bone is broken. No infection yet... the bandages should be changed twice a day.

question: I got a nurse in mind.
answer: The glucose will begin working in half an hour. You'll feel better then...

question: The three of us are going to do some traveling. We're going to take your car to El Paso.
answer: That's not possible. We can't leave here... we've got all this.

question: Is it possible, Mrs. Clinton?
answer: Just... tell us what you want.

question: What kind of car do you have, Harold?
answer: A Ford... We have a Ford.

question: That's good. That's very good. Now Harold, you go out and gas up the Ford, check the oil and tires, we don't want any problems on the road. One more thing... If anybody but you comes back... She gets her clock fixed right away... You understand that, Harold?
answer: You do what he says, Harold.

question: Beer. Guess you have to catch a train?
Me, too. Got twenty-four days of furlough and I'm goin' home.
Utah, the Bee-Hive state. I'm from Orem, right near Salt Lake ... Say, you wouldn't happen to be a Mormon, would you?
Me, neither. There's about twelve people in the state that aren't Mormons and I'm one of them.
answer: That certainly makes you kind of special...

question: Yeah... I guess it does. You wouldn't be taking the train to Salt Lake, would you?
I never have any luck.
answer: I really hope you have a nice trip.

question: Where's the suitcase?
answer: A man helped me open it...

question: And switched keys.
It isn't another boyfriend, is it? How long ago.
Sure? He'd figure you for longer, enough time to try another hit. He's probably still in the station. There better be a guy with the
I don't think you have to worry much about Harold. He won't do anything.
You can trust him...
answer: How long have you been married?

question: Two years.
That's what matters, isn't it?

Look, I'm not going to be any trouble to you either, fact is, this may sound funny, but maybe you and I could be close friends... You don't always have to have your gun out. I'll get whatever you want. Really, I will...
answer: Get rid of that nail polish, I don't like it, and when I tell you to come over here you move fast. You and I are going to get along because I've known a lot of people like you, so don't tell me about it because I got your ticket going in. Now get up and get that paint of your fingers... okay?

question: They may still be going to Nogales.
answer: What about Laughlin in El Paso?

question: Cover both, get someone down there... either Rudy and McCoy's got half a million.
Come here a second... Look, I'm sure you're a nice kid and that your mother's nearby... Your kind of mistakes are going to land me back in Huntsville.
answer: I wouldn't worry Doc. I can always get you out... I'll screw every prison official in Texas if I have to.

question: Texas is a big state.
I'll bet you can.
answer: You'd do the same for me, wouldn't you, Doc? If I was caught, wouldn't you? When we had trouble before it was different.

question: You don't like the way things are, I don't like the way things
answer: What do you want to do?

question: Maybe we should split up... I'll cut the money with you.
I mean it.
answer: No... I don't want to leave.

question: We'll grab a room for tonight then you go out tomorrow and buy yourself some new clothes, pick some up for me... Grab some food now, paper bag it, we eat in the room.
answer: You've got all the answers. What about when they find the body on the train?

question: When they find it, they find it.
No... there's a couple of things I'm still working on.
There may be a hunting party.
answer: Why, there's nothing on the news?

question: I didn't mean police.
Loredo is out. I've been thinking about Rudy. If he was on his own, we're okay. If Beynon bought him out...
If Beynon bought him out, and he talked then maybe Beynon's boys will be waiting for us in El Paso.
I think you liked it with him.
answer: Maybe. At least I got to him. Where do we go from here?

question: El Paso. Thanks. You look great, just great...
answer: That would be the first time.

question: When are you going to learn?
answer: I did I killed a man.

question: And that could be all for you., baby. Now you learn3 this time it could be the chair for both of us. From now on you just shut up and do as you're told.
answer: If I hadn't killed Beynon., you would have.

question: A portable. Yeah. Fifty -- We got trouble. Let's take a walk.
Sure can. I'd like an Invicta 12-gauge pump with the twenty-inch barrel.
Two boxes of double-ought buck.
Might try that.
answer: Sign here. Be one hundred and eighty-five thirty- two.

question: Much obliged.
Let's do it. Slide those guns! Here. Where are you going?
How much?
Are you hungry?
That's okay, honey. Two cheeseburgers; two coffees and a milkshake. Why not?
She made us. Now. Okay?
answer: I think so... I don't know.

question: It's not deep.
No scars. Don't scratch it, just rub, you'll get an infection. Do what I tell you, it's not a game.
answer: It's all a game, don't bother me.

question: We better stick here till tonight.
We're going to make it.
I want to say something.
answer: I don't want to hear it.

question: Listen to me. It's hard enough. Look, what you said yesterday... I guess that was right. It isn't worth anything if we don't make it together.
answer: I don't think we can any more... If we ever get out of here, maybe I should take off...

question: We got this far.
answer: We've come a lot of miles. But we're not close to anything.

question: I guess you're right.
answer: I always thought jails make people hard. Not you. You're just not tough enough to forget about Beynon. I chose you, not him.

question: Either we pick it up or else we leave it right here. We got to go one way or another.
Whatever happens it's over.
You want to try with me?
answer: Things can't get much worse can they?

question: I don't see how.
You and me.
We get to Mexico, we can have a life.
answer: That's all I want... It's the only thing I have ever wanted.

question: Harold, you've had ten minutes, get out of there.
answer: It's hard to figure. There's something about the composition of the track at Pimlico... You can't go by the clock, any speed horse, take a second off any other track in the country. ... but a speed horse is the only thing that consistently holds form. They got to let 'em run, dumb God damn trainers try to rate 'em, just breaks their heart.

question: Okay, sweetpea, you get two choices. Live or die. Do what I tell you, you not only get to live, but maybe you'll pick up some money.
Sure, Doc. I can do it. Just like old times... Yeah, it's a nervous way to live.
Good to see you, Doc. It's all there, departure, arrival - everything except the $500.
Growing -- all of them - every day. 318, you'll be the only ones on the floor.
answer: My lady'11 come in in about five minutes. Have some food sent up in half an hour.

question: Just sandwiches...
answer: Right. When she gets here, have that kid of yours help her with the suitcase.

question: He took the day off.
We've got some food coming, should be here any minute.
answer: Great. I'm going to sleep twelve hours.

question: Ten. Laughlin's going to take us across at four A.M.
Jeep. There's a dry river bed fifteen miles east. He takes us to the Mexican side, drops us off at the airfield by breakfast... we've got a 9 o'clock flight.
Yeah.
I don't know.
answer: Get in the shower. You'll feel okay.

question: Whatever you say. Get upI Carol's eyes snap open. We're moving now!
Laughlin. He's always got his family around... that wife and kid of his have to stand by his side to make sure he stays off the juice and horses.
If they are not here, he must have sent them away.
Get your clothes on, move your butt.
answer: Sorry. Look, I'm clean. I want to get some rest. Who is it?

question: Jump! Drive.
Just fine.
Mexico. I'd like to find a quiet place to cross.
You okay?
answer: Where do we go from here?

question: I don't know, airport I guess.
answer: They will have our description before we can get a plane.

question: That little job cost me a hundred dollars... didn't even get to keep the fish.
answer: Let's just get to the border.

question: Sure thing, mister, it's coming right up. 'Bout an hour. Quiet crossing that is. Chihuahua... gonna do some sightseeing. Which way?
Don't you want to go to the airport?
Pull over. Listen... how much money did you make this year?
Come on. How much?
How about if I buy your car for ten grand?
Sure am.
answer: And I keep my mouth shut?

question: That's what I want.
answer: I don't report the car and I don't know either of you?

question: You got it.
answer: How about twenty thousand? Done, by God.

question: Pay the man. You're going to have to walk back to the border.
answer: Don't worry about me, I'll grab a cab... I can afford it, you know. Hope you get to where you're going.

question: By the way, you're getting a hell of a car there, mister.
answer: Well, I paid a hell of a price. Now for God's sake keep your mouth shut.

question: Wish you hadn't said that. When Slim Canfield's lips are sealed, they're sealed.
